user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarSignal:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarSignal(osal_id_t var_id)
{
    OS_object_token_t token;
    int32             return_code;

    /* Check Parameters */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR, var_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_CondVarSignal_Impl(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR, var_id, &token);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: &token passes the address of a local OS_object_token_t that is intended to be written by OS_ObjectIdGetById (an output parameter). In that case the function parameter must be a non-const pointer, so there is no breach of Rule 8.13. (A violation would occur if OS_ObjectIdGetById does not modify the object but nevertheless declared its parameter as a non-const pointer; then it should accept a pointer to const.)
